contentrichtext.text: {{Other uses|Guajira (disambiguation)}} {{Music of Cuba}} '''Guajira''' ({{lang-es|música guajira}} {{IPA-es|ˈmusika ɣwaˈxiɾa|}}, meaning "country music" in Cuban Spanish) is a musical form which evokes a rural ambience in its texts, instrumentation and style. In the years around 1900 a style of guajira emerged in association with Cuban music theater, especially as composed by [[Jorge Anckermann]]. This genre had some similarity to the [[criolla]]<ref>Orovio, Helio 2004. ''Cuban music from A to Z''. p101</ref> and, to a lesser extent, the punto.<ref>Linares, María Teresa 1999. ''El punto cubano''. La Habana</ref> It contains bucolic countryside lyrics, rhyming, similar to [[décima]] poetry. The music is a mixture of 3/4 and 6/8 rhythms. According to [[Eduardo Sánchez de Fuentes|Sánchez de Fuentes]], its first section is in a minor key, its second section in a major key.<ref>Sánchez de Fuentes, Eduardo 1923. ''El folklore en la música cubana''. La Habana. p56</ref> In general, the songs in this repertoire are no longer well known in Cuba. Hence, for most Cubans, "guajira" connotes a quite different genre that emerged in the 1930s, as a sort of fusion of the ''[[son (music)|son]]'' and the guajira, the "guajira-son," in 4/4 time. It resembled the son in rhythm, but presented a rural ethos by foregrounding the guitar (or tres) more than horns, percussion, or piano. The ''guajira'' could be sung by a single musician accompanying himself on guitar (Orovio 1981:227); see [[trova]]. The lyrics of the ''guajira'' typically extol the beauty of the Cuban countryside and the lifestyle of the ''guajiros'' (countryside peasants). (Alén 1994:64). ==Popularity== ''Guajira'' was refined and popularized by the Cuban [[singer-songwriter]] and [[guitarist]] [[Guillermo Portabales]], whose elegant style has become known as ''guajira de salón''. From the 1930s until his death in a traffic accident in Puerto Rico in 1970, Portabales recorded and performed salon guajira throughout North and South America to tremendous popular acclaim. ''[[Guantanamera]]'', in the form composed and recorded by Joseito Fernández, is a guajira-son which has been covered by many singers and groups. ''Bob Marley And The Wailers'' recorded a song called Guajira Ska in 1964. As the title implies, it was a fusion of guajira and ska. == Spanish version == A Spanish variant of the Guajira has evolved into a form of [[flamenco]] cante (song-type).<ref>Manuel, Peter 2004. The guajira between Cuba and Spain: a study in continuity and change. ''Latin American Music Review'', 22.09.04.</ref><ref>Maria Teresa Linares and Victoria Eli, with Faustino Nunez and Maria de los Angeles Alfonso Rodriguez. 1998, 1999.
